text:
DBMSs rely on data models to define how data is logically organized. The most common models include the Hierarchical Model, Network Model, Relational Model, and Entity-Relationship (ER) Model.

The Relational Model, proposed by E. F. Codd, organizes data into tables (relations). Each table consists of rows (tuples) and columns (attributes).

We also follow a three-level schema architecture:
- The **Internal level** defines physical storage.
- The **Conceptual level** represents the structure of the database for the community of users.
- The **External level** defines different user views.

This separation allows for data abstraction and independence, meaning changes at one level donâ€™t necessarily impact others.
